Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Conductive and Forced-Air Warming in Reducing Intraoperative Hypothermia

Trial_Design.evidence: A prospective randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary healthcare center in the United States.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults scheduled for elective surgery lasting 90-240 minutes. Eligibility criteria included age over 18, fluency in English, and non-cardiac/vascular surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into four groups: (1) CW/CW, (2) FAW/FAW, (3) no active prewarming (NAPW)/CW, and (4) NAPW/FAW.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conductive warming (CW) versus forced-air warming (FAW) in reducing intraoperative hypothermia, with and without prewarming.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the area under the temperature curve (AUC) below 36Â°C, measured intraoperatively using an esophageal probe.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a blocked design, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 182 patients were analysed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 182 patients were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean AUC for CW/CW was 51% lower than NAPW/FAW (ratio 0.49, 95% CI 0.24 to 0.98), and NAPW/CW was 54% lower than NAPW/FAW (ratio 0.46, 95% CI 0.23 to 0.91).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
